Award.AwardTitle: Enriching Computing Curricula through HPC Teaching and Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project at Prairie View A&M University is to improve undergraduate computing education through enhanced courses and research opportunities that incorporate high performance computing (HPC) training that will stimulate students' interest in computing and strengthen their computational problem-solving skills. This project leverages faculty expertise, institutional commitment, industry and federal support to elevate students' computing-related skills and education.

This project is a collaboration of faculty members from three departments - Electrical & Computer Engineering, Computer Science, and Engineering Technology - to develop a diverse high performance computing environment and use it to improve HPC-related education and training at the institution. Six courses will be redesigned to include both embedded and cluster HPC platforms and integrate research topics of the project faculty members. In addition, faculty members will develop new courses in the areas of parallel computing, machine learning, and computer vision. The proposed HPC platforms can easily be expanded to support other disciplines in science technology, engineering, and mathematics.

This project addresses a national need to provide trained graduates in the computing sciences in order to help the U.S. retain its technological competitiveness. Almost 500 undergraduate students, the majority of whom are African American, will be impacted during the three project years. Each year, high school teachers and university faculty members will receive training. Research data, source code, and curriculum materials generated by this project will be posted online and disseminated in conferences and publications for the research and educational community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today's scientists and engineers depend increasingly on information and tools made available through new advanced computing technologies. High Performance Computing (HPC) now plays a critical role in enabling such scientific and engineering inquiry. A group of faculty members from Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) realized the computing curricula did not adequately cover HPC contents, thus resulted in the lacking of experience in how HPC functions among undergraduate students. So, they acquired NSF HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion support to enrich computing curricula through HPC teaching and research.

The overarching goal of this project is to improve undergraduate computing education at PVAMU through enhanced courses and research opportunities that incorporate HPC training in order to motivate students? interests in computing and strengthen their computing problem-solving skills, thus strengthening and diversifying the future U.S. workforce.

The anticipated outcomes of this project include an increase of underrepresented groups (African American, Hispanic, and Women) in computing discipline, who demonstrate that they can utilize HPC to solve engineering problems. After years of implementation, this project:

(1)  Deployed a novel HPC research and educational platform through engineering computational laboratory;

(2)  Revamped existing and developed new computing courses in the context of HPC across three departments;

(3)  Improved student performance and critical thinking in HPC related areas;

(4)  Involved undergraduate students in research, and prepared them with lifelong learning skills;

(5)  Propelled faculty professional development and established a scholar community to promote faculty collaborations through training workshop;

(6)  Increased the awareness of cutting-edge computing techniques to K-12 students as well as general public.

Specifically, five new undergraduate courses were developed to cover the emerging areas of HPC, machine learning, parallel programming, computer vision, and embedded system. Eight existing courses were revamped with new teaching modules from HPC hardware, software, and applications. Class surveys were collected and analyzed to prove the effectiveness of the curricula enhancement. Conference and journal publications were published to disseminate this project. Eight senior design groups were supported throughout the project years. The project team mentored nearly twenty undergraduate students to work on various computing research projects. The supplement award supported graduate students to finish their research and defended their theses.

This project also involved extra curriculum activities. For example, it supported a team to participate in 2018 IEEE Region 5 Robotics Competition. The team got very good result (tied in the 11th place). Beyond that, the project supported the establishment of PVAMU Robotics Club. This is an association provided both hardware and software training for robotics design. It also sponsored the annual PVAMU robotics competition. Students gained valuable experience on embedded system design and computer vision algorithms. The project provided many training opportunities for undergraduate students. During major semesters, one-day Intel workshop was conducted. It also co-sponsored the PVAMU Annual IEEE workshop. In 2019, the technical sub-topic was "Artificial Intelligent." A whole afternoon training on Python obtained good feedback. In summer semester, it co-sponsored multi-day workshops on big data analysis.

Besides curricula enrichment and students mentoring, faculty members also enhanced their teaching and research capabilities through this project. All of them added one new course to their class offering list, expanded their research areas, and obtained new findings to extend their previous research.

To summarize, this is a well implemented project which focused on improving the key technique among undergraduate engineering students. All the goals are achieved and proposed outcomes are met.
